just want to quickly talk about is the difference between AI and machine learning because those terms are quite

about imbuing software and systems with human-like characteristics and enabling
applications to do things that historically and traditionally only the human mind has
been able to do something as simple as root finding for example or as complicated as figuring out whether
somebody you're looking at is happy or sad or upset those are things that just a few short years ago you definitely
needed a person to do but today you can hand those functions over to software and you can do so in a way which is
reliable very effective and Amazon we put that to work but of course like you
we create those artificially intelligent systems by using a process and that
process is machine learning combining data normally labeled or annotated data
together with algorithms and from those two inputs building a model that we can
then use to make predictions okay those predictions might be about the emotion of a face that we're seeing a photograph
or they might be about the most effective way to lay out inventory in a warehouse or the most effective way to
route a device like this an Amazon Fulfillment robot around one of our fulfillment centers to enable us to
deliver a better customer experience Jeff Bezos always said focus on the
things that don't change in business not on the things that do can you ever imagine a situation where one of our
customers might say I'd like you to ship me things more slowly and in a less
accurate way no of course not so work hard on the things that are constant try
to improve them and you'll deliver a better service for customers in our case its innovations like this changing the
way in which our fulfillment centers work so that rather than our team's having to go out and find inventory in
the fulfillment center the inventory comes to them these robots will pick up the inventory bring it to the human
beings the human beings can pick the inventory out of the packing devices that you can see on top of these robots
place it into a dispatch cray ultimately it finds its way into the postal service or into a courier and it arrives at your
door okay accurate fast very efficient okay we also use computer vision at the
end of that process to establish that we've put the right thing in the package so that we dispatch actually

same process of course we also have recommendation engines or recommender systems as we call them it's a

in the UK where I'm from Amazon stocks about a hundred million different inventory items okay so what you've got

okay we use a specific machine learning technique here called factorization machines that are able to operate with

Singapore to London I want to fly to London from Singapore I need a flight
from Singapore I need to fly to London I need to fly to London from Singapore on Thursday at 10 a.m.
see how many different derivatives there are for me to say pretty much the same thing and I want a natural experience
here so I don't want to have to go back and reactor what their origin or

play me BBC Radio one can you tell me how long it's going to get to Heathrow
Airport all these different intents able to resolve them down using classification algorithms figure out
what it is the user is asking for connect them to the business logic to generate the response convert it back
into natural voice and play that out to the user and do all that in a time
period that makes it still feel natural and easy to use without a big delay okay
so it's quite a difficult challenge to solve but I think we did a pretty good job this is a very very popular device
as a result of that and a couple of years ago AWS customers were asking
